title: Well I did it, I snapped and raged super hard at my support.

replies.body:
You could always mute people.  

Unfortunately, verbally abusing someone who is abusing you is not the correct response.  The best thing is to mute someone if they are saying things that are bothering you.  You can still see their pings and they can see yours, so no communication is missed.

Any time someone ever started raging I would instantly mute.
Early and mid is fine but without actual communication late game I always lost.

Pings were introduced for the sole reason of being able to mute people and not lose communication. When I mute the rager in my team I only see their plays, I even congratulate them, because I forget that they are dicks. xD It's never the lack of communication losing the game, it's more my allies and the rager not paying attention anymore.

^This. Yea, its the PROPER thing to do by technicality, but someone punches you, any person is going to be pissed and defend themselves. It's NATURAL to defend yourself. Forcing people to go against what should be a right is kind of screwed IMO.
If some jerk walks over and punches you, you can have him/her arrested and charged.  Getting into a brawl doesn't solve anything, and it's a lot more likely to get you both thrown in jail.
that means you HAVE to rely on someone else to deal with your problem instead of solving it yourself. yes, the problem is solved, but you did nothing but throw it upon someone else

Relying on someone else to deal with your problems is the entire foundation of modern society.  I don't want to deal with the problem of gathering my own food, so I pay other people to do it for me.  The same applies to violence; I don't want to deal with the problem of getting myself arrested, so I pay other people to arrest the aggressor for me.

More importantly, does me deciding to punch the guy that punched me in retaliation solve the problem?  I would argue that it doesn't, especially since it can result in much bigger problems for myself down the line.

I almost never say this to people who post about rage.

I don't think you were out of line. If I were in game, I would not have reported you. I probably *would* have reported Leona, if she's going in 3v5 when you said you'd be elsewhere and then blaming you when she loses the fight.

I'm more of a tilter than a rager, but here are a couple of things that have helped me skate through some of these situations without vomiting creative strings of cuss words on the offender (which I have sometimes done, I admit.)

If you can, make a joke out of it. Especially if it's just a playful joke at your own expense, this can relieve the tension. For example:

"wtf are you talking about, kid? Just got promoted to Bronze 3. I'm the fucking best. ;)"

Follow up with a calm explanation of why she's out to lunch, so she doesn't think you're a troll.

"But seriously, I told you I'd be taking red. You can engage without me if you want, but don't blame me when you lose the fight."

If neither of these seems like it'd be effective, just type in all-chat:

"This toxic Leona . . . "

Usually, if she's a legitimate problem, they'll understand, and report the right person.

Really, though, these boards need a Rage Support Group. It might help people out if they know they can just kvetch to sympathetic ears after the game.

I'm probably going to come off as harsh, but you just need to get over what other people think or do. I can almost guarantee you won't get a chat restriction or ban if you aren't actually abusive. I defend myself, I am in no way nice about it, and I have even flamed people. Yet I have never been warned, banned, or restricted. 


The trick is don't get baited into a he did she did argument. State your defense rationally, one time, and leave it at that. Possibly ask them to focus on the game in a non-provocative manner. The fact that you aren't responding to their emotions will either make them shut up, or cause them to go into a blinding rage because. Either situation is fine, because in the latter you just mute and report since they'll have pissed the rest of your team off. Just don't appear like you're also raging. Don't ask for teammates or enemies support. Don't make it about proving yourself to the rager-you won't change him. And never be the first one to talk in all chat. As long as it's clear you want to play the game, not talk, you'll get less reports than someone who is purely raging. Also, people who frequently put out false reports have their reports valued down. It's possible to have the system almost ignore someone's reports. So don't worry that you can get restricted because someone has a tantrum. If they're inclined to report people for trivial shit, their reports are probably worthless.

I have a number or problems with how Riot does stuff, but I don't believe people get punished for behavior things wrongly. You can defend yourself, but if vindicating yourself becomes more important than winning, you're no better than the rager. Like I said, just use a non emotional response based on fact.

You could say that. You can't be punished for saying -exactly- that. The thing people get punished for is saying something -like- that but with a couple ... little... changes.
''Noob, stop crying about me. You pushed with no wards and got your dumb ass handed to you for it. It's not my fault you're a moron.''
-That- can get you punished. (And then the people who get punished are shocked that they got punished because they couldn't possibly be toxic if they aren't swearing...)

-However-, I don't really recommend getting into it. Trying to place blame is only going to fuel the fire. Most people recognize excuse-making when they see it, which is what blaming someone else for your own death is, with very few exceptions (Blitz or Darius pulling in the wrong target and giving them a free gap close and a bad Bard ult can really screw you over in ways that you can't really play around and still play with your team. They usually know what they did wrong though and blaming them in chat is only going to create bad feeling among the team.)

With a rager like your support in that game, I would have muted them very early and reported them at the end of the game. I'm not going to listen to that crap. 

In general I don't have a lot of use for chat, TBH. It does get me free kills sometimes though, when someone is standing in the middle of the lane venting their rage at length and scrambles to even start moving around the time their health bar hits zero. I'll never understand how people have time to get into these lengthy arguments. If you're a laner, you should be CSing, shopping, or positioning for the next objective or fight. If you're a support you should be warding, sweeping, shopping, or positioning for harass, peel, the next objective, or the next fight. If you're a jungler, you should be farming, warding, sweeping, or shopping -- and looking for the next gank or objective opportunity at the same time or postioning for such a gank or objective. Maybe once every 3-5 minutes I might be autopathing such a long distance that I have time to type a couple whole sentences. Usually I only take the time to say things like 'drag under 1min' or whatever when a single ping is not going to send a clear message. (Nobody gets it when I ping an empty dragon pit.)

I simply have no time to play the blame-game or get dragged down into toxic fights when there's a match going on. Nobody who wants to win their game does, actually, even though many seem to believe all that time standing still and arguing is somehow going to help.
